titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: William Cummings and Son were shipping merchants in Philadelphia. William Cummings (b. 1806) went into business with his uncle (also named William Cummings) in 1826. In 1830 he went into business for himself. He owned several schooners, brigs, barques, and ships, including the ship William Cummings. Some time before 1864, Cummings' son, Norris S. Cummings, joined the business. Over its history, the firm operated out of various locations near the Delaware River, including South Delaware Avenue, Walnut Street and Dock Street. The firm was in operation until at least 1880.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of William Cummings and Son. The collection consists of three volumes. The first volume is a receipt book (1864-1879) of the firm of William Cummings and Son, listing amounts paid for crew wages, pilotage, wharfage, labor and supplies. The ships William Cummings and Ann Elizabeth are mentioned frequently in this volume. The second volume is a letterbook of the firm kept between 1853 and 1866. Letters to ships' captains and merchants discuss market conditions, shipments of goods, bills and accounts, damages to vessels, and other business matters. This volume also includes several lists of cargoes and notes on freights and freighting. The third volume is a record book of a voyage of the ship William Cummings from Callao, Peru to Calcutta, India, to Philadelphia, PA (1858-1859). Most entries list winds, weather, courses, and remarks on unusual occurrences, such as punishments of crew. This volume also includes logs of the time the ship was in harbor in Callao and Calcutta, and a list of stores received at Calcutta.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
